abstract: GRIDLOCK AHEAD? With 750 million domestic passengers expected to fly this year, “the air transportation system is stretched thin,” the Federal Aviation Administration said in a report. It called for increased financing for "major technology upgrades and capacity-improvement projects at major airports" to avoid what the agency said would be aviation “gridlock.” Last year, the F.A.A. said, airline delays were “the worst in history.” DELTA HELICOPTER SHUTTLE US Helicopter, which operates helicopter shuttles with 325 flights a week to Kennedy International and Newark airports and Bridgeport, Conn., is now flying into Delta Air Lines Terminal 3 at Kennedy, rather than American Airlines Terminal 9. One-way fares for the eight-minute trip from Manhattan to Kennedy or Newark start at $159. At Newark, the shuttles land next to Continental Airlines Terminal C.

lead_paragraph: GRIDLOCK AHEAD? With 750 million domestic passengers expected to fly this year, “the air transportation system is stretched thin,” the Federal Aviation Administration said in a report. It called for increased financing for "major technology upgrades and capacity-improvement projects at major airports" to avoid what the agency said would be aviation “gridlock.” Last year, the F.A.A. said, airline delays were “the worst in history.” DELTA HELICOPTER SHUTTLE  US Helicopter, which operates helicopter shuttles with 325 flights a week to Kennedy International and Newark airports and Bridgeport, Conn., is now flying into Delta Air Lines Terminal 3 at Kennedy, rather than American Airlines Terminal 9. One-way fares for the eight-minute trip from Manhattan to Kennedy or Newark start at $159. At Newark, the shuttles land next to Continental Airlines Terminal C.
